articles.headline: U.S. Attack on I.C.C. Is Seen as Bolstering World’s Despots
articles.snippet: John R. Bolton’s critique of the International Criminal Court echoes criticisms from dictators and threatens the future of the court, the U.N.’s war-crimes prosecution mechanism.
articles.abstract: John R. Bolton’s critique of the International Criminal Court echoes criticisms from dictators and threatens the future of the court, the U.N.’s war-crimes prosecution mechanism.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — In a city that symbolizes international peace and justice, the ambassador from Burundi has had a lonely job. As her government faces accusations of murder, rape and torture, she has made the unpopular argument that the International Criminal Court should butt out.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Marlise Simons

articles.headline: Stealing From a Cashierless Store (Without You, or the Cameras, Knowing It)
articles.snippet: A start-up uses visual tracking and behavioral data to operate a new San Francisco market, which lets shoppers walk out unimpeded. And sometimes mischarged.
articles.abstract: A start-up uses visual tracking and behavioral data to operate a new San Francisco market, which lets shoppers walk out unimpeded. And sometimes mischarged.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One recent afternoon, the city’s newest grocery market was trying to figure out whether I would buy, steal or leave behind a bag of white Cheddar popcorn — and so was I.

articles.headline: Dozens of Homes Burn in Andover and Lawrence, Mass., Gas Explosions
articles.snippet: One person was killed and more than 20 were injured in the explosions, which the governor of Massachusetts said were caused by gas leaks.
articles.abstract: One person was killed and more than 20 were injured in the explosions, which the governor of Massachusetts said were caused by gas leaks.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAWRENCE, Mass. — Violent explosions and billowing fires tore through three towns north of Boston late Thursday afternoon, damaging dozens of houses, forcing thousands of stunned residents to evacuate and plunging much of the region into an eerie darkness.
articles.byline: By Katharine Q. Seelye, Farah Stockman, Jacey Fortin and Monica Davey

articles.headline: As the Winds Come, Towns in Hurricane Florence’s Path Fear the Floods
articles.snippet: The storm surge in the Carolinas could be deadly. But for inland towns, it’s the water that will fall afterward that could really bring disaster.
articles.abstract: The storm surge in the Carolinas could be deadly. But for inland towns, it’s the water that will fall afterward that could really bring disaster.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the latest updates on Hurricane Florence, read our Friday live briefing here.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset, Campbell Robertson and David Zucchino

articles.headline: At a Divided Network, What Now for CBS News and ‘60 Minutes’?
articles.snippet: In its half-century on the air, “60 Minutes” has operated independently of the CBS News organization. Many at the show worry what will happen if the network takes more control.
articles.abstract: In its half-century on the air, “60 Minutes” has operated independently of the CBS News organization. Many at the show worry what will happen if the network takes more control.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, the headquarters of CBS News and the offices of “60 Minutes” have stood on opposite sides of a windswept block of Manhattan’s West 57th Street.
articles.byline: By John Koblin and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Paul Manafort Agrees to Cooperate With Special Counsel; Pleads Guilty to Reduced Charges
articles.snippet: The plea deal by President Trump’s former campaign chairman was a victory for Robert S. Mueller III’s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.
articles.abstract: The plea deal by President Trump’s former campaign chairman was a victory for Robert S. Mueller III’s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Paul Manafort agreed on Friday to tell all he knows to the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, as part of a plea deal that could shape the final stages of the inquiry into Russian interference in the 2016 election.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: Mary Meeker, ‘Queen of the Internet,’ Is Leaving Kleiner Perkins to Start a New Fund
articles.snippet: Ms. Meeker, a former Wall Street tech analyst, plans to invest in more mature and larger private companies at her spinoff from the venture capital firm.
articles.abstract: Ms. Meeker, a former Wall Street tech analyst, plans to invest in more mature and larger private companies at her spinoff from the venture capital firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The “Queen of the Internet” will soon have her own investment firm.

articles.headline: In This North Carolina Coastal Town, ‘Downtown Is Literally Underwater’
articles.snippet: Hundreds were rescued from flood-marooned homes overnight, with another 150 awaiting rescue. “We are praying and hoping for the best,” one resident said.
articles.abstract: Hundreds were rescued from flood-marooned homes overnight, with another 150 awaiting rescue. “We are praying and hoping for the best,” one resident said.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW BERN, N.C. — There is plenty of past in this city, 308 years of it: colonial governors, Union troops, communities of freed slaves and yes, hurricanes, plenty of them. But none of it, at least nothing that anyone alive could remember, seemed to prepare New Bern for Hurricane Florence.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Campbell Robertson
